questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever and sore throat. This morning, she noticed a rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet. He does not have pruritus. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows oral vesicles. A photograph of the rash on the feet is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis due to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular oral lesions. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is not usually associated with a rash, HSV-1 infection can trigger erythema multiforme (EM). EM, which typically begins on the extremities before spreading to the palms and soles, can also present as a papulovesicular rash. However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

B) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.
Image Description:

A diffuse rash is seen in various stages of lesion evolution (starry-sky appearance), with mainly ruptured vesicles and crusted erosions seen here.

These findings are typical for chickenpox.

C) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. Oral vesicles can easily rupture and cause painful ulcers. In some cases, the arms, legs, and buttocks are also affected. The illness is typically self-limiting. Coxsackie A virus can also cause pharyngitis and herpangina.

Unlike coxsackie A virus, coxsackie B virus does not cause oral or cutaneous disease. It instead causes acute myocarditis, pericarditis, and pleurodynia.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. However, the rubella exanthem is maculopapular rather than vesicular and it typically begins on the face before spreading caudally with sparing of the palms and soles. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

A nonconfluent, pink, maculopapular rash is visible across this infant's trunk and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 causes roseola infantum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears several days after the onset of fever. However, the rash is macular, not vesicular and typically begins only after cessation of fever, whereas this patient is still febrile. Moreover, the rash appears initially on the trunk; the involvement of palms and soles is rare. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal papules (Nagayama spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photograph of a 1-year-old child with recent febrile illness

A patchy, nonpruritic, blanching, erythematous rash with macules and papules can be seen on the trunk and arms. Symptoms manifested one day after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

F) INCORRECT:

In children, parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears a few days after the onset of fever. However, the rash of erythema infectiosum is characterized by malar erythema (“slapped cheek” appearance), circumoral pallor, and lace-like or reticular lesions on the trunk. Neither vesicular lesions nor the involvement of palms and soles would be expected.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

G) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a rash that occurs either in response to the infection itself or following the administration of a penicillin antibiotic. However, the rash of infectious mononucleosis is maculopapular, not vesicular and appears initially on the trunk; the involvement of palms and soles is rare. Examination of the oral cavity can reveal exudative tonsillar enlargement and palatal petechiae but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with a pruritic rash associated with the administration of an aminopenicillin for suspected bacterial tonsillitis.

There is an erythematous, patchy, partly confluent, maculopapular rash.

This appearance is typical of an aminopenicillin-related rash, seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever and a non-itchy rash. The mother reports that he has had difficulty eating since yesterday. He has not had a cough, nausea, or vomiting. He was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Examination shows tender, erythematous macules and papules over the knees, buttocks, palms, and soles. There are multiple 2-mm ulcers on the buccal mucosa. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 causes roseola infantum, which manifests with fever, a nonpruritic maculopapular exanthem that can extend to the extremities, and occasionally an enanthem. However, the exanthem is nontender, occurs only after the fever subsides (fever due to roseola lasts for 3–7 days), predominantly affects the trunk, and does not affect the palms and soles. The enanthem of roseola infantum (Nagayama spots) is characterized by erythematous papules rather than ulcers.

B) INCORRECT:

Rubella manifests with fever and a maculopapular exanthem that typically arises on the face and then spreads to the trunk and extremities. In some cases, an enanthem may be present (Forchheimer sign) but these appear as petechiae rather than ulcers. Moreover, the exanthem of rubella is nontender, does not affect the palms and soles, and is preceded by a prodromal phase with postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. This patient's up-to-date immunization status also makes rubella very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 1 causes herpetic gingivostomatitis, which can also manifest with fever and ulcerative enanthem. However, the condition is restricted to the oral cavity rather than presenting with eruption on other parts of the body.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

D) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus causes HFMD, which affects primarily infants and young children and is characterized by fever, an enanthem of the oral cavity, and a nonpruritic exanthem that mainly involves the palms and soles but can occasionally spread to the limbs and buttocks. A prodromal phase is usually absent. The exanthem is often initially maculopapular and progresses to vesicular lesions that can ulcerate. The various morphologies of the exanthem may be present simultaneously and the exanthem can occasionally be tender (with certain Coxsackie A serotypes). The enanthem is typically painful (causing odynophagia or refusal to eat), appears as erythematous macules, vesicles, or ulcers, and most commonly involves the tongue or buccal mucosa. The disease is most often self-limiting and supportive treatment (e.g., pain relief) is usually sufficient. Rarely, patients can develop neurological complications (e.g., meningitis).

See “Overview of infectious rashes in childhood” table.
Image Description:

12-month-old infant

Typical white-gray blisters with a diameter of approx. 3–5 mm surrounded by an erythematous halo are seen on the fingers (top images). Another common finding, as seen here, is a disseminated macular and papular rash on the upper and lower legs (bottom left). In addition, there is a partially crusted papulovesicular rash in the perioral region (bottom right). However, the eponymous involvement of the mouth refers to the typically painful aphthous enanthem of the oral mucosa, which is not shown here.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which is characterized by a rash that typically starts on the trunk and then spreads to the entire body, and in some cases, the oral mucosa as well as the palms and soles. The localization of this patient's rash is different from the one seen in chickenpox. Furthermore, chickenpox is characterized by a nontender but itchy rash with various stages (i.e., papules, vesicles, crusts) that appear simultaneously. Chickenpox is also unlikely because of the patient's up-to-date immunization status.

F) INCORRECT:

Measles manifests with fever, a maculopapular exanthem, and an enanthem but it also causes cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 C's!), which this patient does not have. Moreover, the exanthem of measles rarely involves the palms and soles and the enanthem of measles (Koplik spots) is characterized by white or bluish-white spots rather than ulcers. This patient's up-to-date immunization status also makes measles very unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 causes fifth disease, which manifests with a flu-like prodrome that is followed by a maculopapular exanthem 7–10 days later that classically causes a slapped-cheek appearance and sometimes spreads to the trunk and limbs. The exanthem of fifth disease is nontender and does not involve the palms and soles. Moreover, fifth disease does not manifest with an enanthem.

H) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus causes impetigo. The disease affects primarily the face and extremities and typically presents with honey-colored vesicles, pustules, or crusted lesions on an erythematous background. The lesions are rarely painful and patients are typically afebrile. Impetigo can cause perioral lesions but does not typically cause an enanthem.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD).

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department in late summer shortly after an episode of sudden loss of consciousness with uncontrolled shaking of the entire body and facial twitching. Her mother reports that the event lasted for about 2 minutes and that her daughter quickly returned to normal afterward. For the past 24 hours, the girl has had a fever and a sore throat. She has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears weak but is alert, oriented, and responds appropriately in short sentences. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is 2 seconds. Examination of the oral cavity shows the findings in the photograph. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and ceftriaxone are the empiric therapy of choice for patients between 1 month and 50 years of age with suspected bacterial meningitis. While meningitis can manifest with fever and seizures, further features such as headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina, for which antibiotic therapy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the head is indicated in patients with suspected meningitis and signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., focal neurologic deficits) prior to a lumbar puncture, or after a complex febrile seizure to rule out structural causes. While meningitis can manifest with fever and new-onset seizures, further features such as headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (i.e., a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina; therefore, a CT scan of the head is not appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Simple febrile seizures occur among children 6 months to 5 years of age, are generalized tonic-clonic seizures, last < 15 minutes, do not recur within 24 hours, and are usually followed by a quick return to a normal state without focal neurologic deficits. Simple febrile seizures do not require specific diagnostic workup if the cause of fever is known and neurologic examination is unremarkable. Diagnosis of herpangina is established clinically and treatment consists of supportive care only, since the condition is typically self-limited. Antipyretic therapy (NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, or acetaminophen) is the treatment of choice for symptomatic relief of herpangina as well as for fever reduction after a febrile seizure. Children with herpangina who are dehydrated (as evidenced by, e.g., prolonged capillary refill time) due to decreased oral intake should be admitted to hospital and receive parenteral fluids.
Image Description:

Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

A throat swab for a rapid group A streptococcus (GAS) antigen detection test and empiric penicillin therapy are indicated in patients with suspected GAS tonsillopharyngitis, which also manifests with sudden onset of fever, sore throat, and tonsillopharyngeal erythema. However, GAS tonsillopharyngitis is typically associated with gray-white tonsillar exudates and edema rather than multiple small, white vesicles like the ones seen here. This patient presents with herpangina, for which a throat swab is not required and penicillin therapy is ineffective.
Image Description:

Oral cavity of a child presenting with fever, dysphagia, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy

The pharyngeal tonsils are enlarged, erythematous, edematous, and have streaks of mucopurulent discharge bilaterally.

This is the typical appearance of bilateral acute tonsillitis.

E) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture (LP) is indicated in patients with suspected meningitis or encephalitis, both of which can manifest with fever and new-onset seizures. However, further features (e.g., headache, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits) are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina; LP is not indicated in patients who appear well with a known cause of fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy is indicated in herpetic gingivostomatitis, which also manifests with painful, small oral lesions, fever, and sore throat. In addition, herpetic gingivostomatitis can be complicated by herpes simplex (HSV) encephalitis, which can also manifest with seizures. However, the lesions in herpetic gingivostomatitis are commonly located on the anterior oropharynx, tongue, lips, and perioral skin (as opposed to the posterior oropharynx in this child) and are preceded by a prodromal phase with several days of fever and malaise. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other expected symptoms of HSV encephalitis (e.g., altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits). More likely this patient had a simple febrile seizure due to herpangina, for which acyclovir is not indicated.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows multiple small, white vesicles and an erythematous rim on the inner lip, uvula, soft palate, tonsillar pillars, and buccal mucosa of the lip. These findings are characteristic of herpangina, a Coxsackie A virus infection that is typically accompanied by high fever and, therefore, poses a risk for febrile seizures.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, fully immunized 18-month-old boy presents with 3 days of fever and rash.
His temperature is 39.0°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 34 breaths per minute. He has a rash on his hands and feet (figure) and oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum is a common pediatric condition caused by infection with parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a slapped-cheek appearance and a lacy reticular rash on the torso and extremities. It does not cause a vesicular eruption.

B) INCORRECT:

HSV types 1 and 2 can cause herpetic gingivostomatitis and herpetic whitlow (an infection of the digits), but lesions are usually confined to the anterior mouth — and when present on extraoral surfaces such as digits, they are usually singular, not scattered bilaterally over the palms and soles as in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpangina, which is also caused by an enterovirus, is an acute febrile illness that leads to small vesicles and ulcers in the posterior oropharynx but not on the extremities as in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by coxsackievirus A16. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is characterized by a vesicular eruption on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet. Cutaneous vesicles are typically surrounded by an erythematous base and will eventually ulcerate. Oral vesicles are usually located on the buccal mucosa and tongue and are mildly painful.

Treatment for hand, foot, and mouth disease is supportive, and most children recover within one week.

The differential diagnosis for hand, foot, and mouth disease includes other vesicle-causing infections such as herpangina, varicella-zoster virus, and herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of fever with vesicular rash on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet, as well as oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue, of a fully immunized 18-month-old child is hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by infection with coxsackievirus A16.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella lesions tend to appear more centrally on the body and to spare the palms and soles. Although a single vaccine is not completely protective, wild-type disease is becoming rarer with universal vaccination.

questions.text:
A fully immunized 2-year-old boy with no significant medical history presents with 2 days of fever, new-onset sore throat, and lesions on his right hand. His mother reports that multiple children in his day-care center have had similar symptoms.
His temperature is 39.2°C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is normal. His condition does not appear toxic, and his eyes and nose are normal. His oropharynx is notable for erythema and palatal ulcers. His right hand is shown (figure).
Which one of the following viruses is most likely causing this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenovirus infections of the upper respiratory tract are common and often subclinical, but they can cause common cold symptoms, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, otitis media, and pharyngoconjunctival fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Rhinoviruses most commonly cause common cold symptoms or rhinosinusitis and can be associated with pharyngitis, otitis media, and lower respiratory tract infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Most primary herpes simplex virus infections manifesting in childhood beyond the neonatal period are asymptomatic. In childhood, gingivostomatitis is the most common clinical manifestation of herpes simplex virus.

D) CORRECT:

In infants and children, fever, palatal ulcers, and blisters on the hands and feet are symptoms of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is most often caused by an enterovirus (coxsackievirus A16). The blisters on the hands and feet are typically in a palmar and plantar distribution but can be anywhere on the extremities.

Enterovirus infection most commonly causes nonspecific febrile illness. Other manifestations include coryza; pharyngitis; herpangina; stomatitis; pneumonia; pleurodynia; hand, foot, and mouth disease; aseptic meningitis; encephalitis; vomiting; diarrhea; orchitis; acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis; and uveitis. Myocarditis and pericarditis are also caused by enteroviruses.

Testing for enterovirus in a healthy child with uncomplicated disease (such as this presentation of typical hand, foot, and mouth disease) is usually not indicated. When testing is necessary, the virus can be detected by a polymerase chain-reaction test or cultured from rectal and throat swabs, tracheal aspirates, urine, blood, or tissue biopsy specimens during the acute illness. Enterovirus detected by polymerase chain-reaction testing of cerebrospinal fluid can be helpful in the evaluation of patients with aseptic meningitis.

Key learning point: Hand, foot, and mouth disease is most often caused by an enterovirus, especially coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus 71.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster virus can cause a febrile illness with a vesicular rash eruption (chicken pox), but the lesions are not typically isolated to the palms. The lesions associated with varicella start on the torso, are often noted to be in various stages of healing, and are quite pruritic. The incidence of varicella has declined significantly because of the vaccine, which is given at 12 months of age and then again at 4 to 5 years of age.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a low-grade fever, sore throat, oral vesicular lesions, and a nonpruritic rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet shown in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis due to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular oral lesions. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is not usually associated with a rash, HSV-1 infection can trigger erythema multiforme (EM). EM, which typically begins on the extremities before spreading to the palms and soles, can also present as a papulovesicular rash. However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

B) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.
Image Description:

A diffuse rash is seen in various stages of lesion evolution (starry-sky appearance), with mainly ruptured vesicles and crusted erosions seen here.

These findings are typical for chickenpox.

C) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. Oral vesicles can easily rupture and cause painful ulcers. In some cases, the arms, legs, and buttocks are also affected. The illness is typically self-limiting. Coxsackie A virus can also cause pharyngitis and herpangina.

Unlike coxsackie A virus, coxsackie B virus does not cause oral or cutaneous disease. It instead causes acute myocarditis, pericarditis, and pleurodynia.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. However, the rubella exanthem is maculopapular rather than vesicular and it typically begins on the face before spreading caudally with sparing of the palms and soles. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

A nonconfluent, pink, maculopapular rash is visible across this infant's trunk and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

In children, parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears a few days after the onset of fever. However, the rash of erythema infectiosum is characterized by malar erythema (“slapped cheek” appearance), circumoral pallor, and lace-like or reticular lesions on the trunk. Neither vesicular lesions nor the involvement of palms and soles would be expected.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: A previously healthy, fully immunized 18-month-old boy presents with 3 days of fever and rash. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 34/min. He has a rash on his hands and feet (figure) and oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum is a common pediatric condition caused by infection with parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a slapped-cheek appearance and a lacy reticular rash on the torso and extremities. It does not cause a vesicular eruption.

B) INCORRECT:

HSV types 1 and 2 can cause herpetic gingivostomatitis and herpetic whitlow (an infection of the digits), but lesions are usually confined to the anterior mouth — and when present on extraoral surfaces such as digits, they are usually singular, not scattered bilaterally over the palms and soles as in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpangina, which is also caused by an enterovirus, is an acute febrile illness that leads to small vesicles and ulcers in the posterior oropharynx but not on the extremities as in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by coxsackievirus A16. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is characterized by a vesicular eruption on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet. Cutaneous vesicles are typically surrounded by an erythematous base and will eventually ulcerate. Oral vesicles are usually located on the buccal mucosa and tongue and are mildly painful.

Treatment for hand, foot, and mouth disease is supportive, and most children recover within one week.

The differential diagnosis for hand, foot, and mouth disease includes other vesicle-causing infections such as herpangina, varicella-zoster virus, and herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of fever with vesicular rash on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet, as well as oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue, of a fully immunized 18-month-old child is hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by infection with coxsackievirus A16.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella lesions tend to appear more centrally on the body and to spare the palms and soles. Although a single vaccine is not completely protective, wild-type disease is becoming rarer with universal vaccination.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. His mother reports multiple small, painful oral lesions that emerged yesterday. Examination reveals multiple 1- to 2-mm grayish vesicles on the soft palate and uvula, each with an erythematous halo. The anterior oral mucosa and gingiva appear normal, and there is no prominent lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following viruses is the most likely etiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 1 typically causes primary herpetic gingivostomatitis in children, presenting with widespread vesicular lesions on the lips, anterior oral mucosa, and gingiva, often with gingival inflammation and cervical lymphadenopathy. The lesions in this patient are confined to the soft palate and uvula, which is not characteristic of HSV-1 infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) causes chickenpox, characterized by a generalized vesicular rash on the trunk, face, and extremities, with lesions in various stages. The lesion distribution in this patient is confined to the soft palate and uvula, inconsistent with the widespread rash of VZV. VZV reactivation presents with a dermatomal distribution, not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, presenting with prolonged fever, pharyngitis with tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient has localized vesicles on the soft palate and uvula, characteristic of herpangina, not the diffuse or exudative pharyngitis typical of EBV infection.

D) CORRECT:

Herpangina, commonly caused by Coxsackie A virus, manifests in children with fever, sore throat, and odynophagia. It is characterized by small, grayish vesicles with an erythematous halo on the soft palate and uvula, sparing the anterior mouth. This lesion distribution distinguishes herpangina from other viral infections. The condition is self-limiting, managed with supportive care for symptom relief. Recognizing these features in pediatric patients aids in clinical diagnosis based on lesion distribution and systemic symptoms.

Key learning point: Herpangina is characterized by fever and vesicular lesions on the soft palate and posterior pharynx, commonly caused by Coxsackie A virus, and is distinct from aphthous ulcers and gingival cysts.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with 2 days of fever, irritability, and decreased appetite. His mother notes a rash on his hands and feet that began yesterday. He has up-to-date immunizations and no known drug allergies. Examination shows slightly dry mucous membranes, mild tachycardia, and multiple small vesicles on the palms and soles. Several painful ulcers are seen on the palate (see image). Minimal urine output is reported since the morning. No neck stiffness is present.


Heart rate
130/min


Temperature
38.0°C


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is effective against herpesviruses, not enteroviruses like Coxsackievirus, which causes hand, foot, and mouth disease. Herpetic gingivostomatitis typically involves extensive oral lesions without the characteristic palm and sole vesicles seen here, making acyclovir inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Empirical antibiotic therapy is indicated for suspected bacterial infections, such as sepsis or meningitis. This child’s symptoms, including a vesicular rash on the palms and soles and oral ulcers, suggest a viral etiology, specifically hand, foot, and mouth disease. The absence of high-grade fever, purulence, or systemic toxicity reduces the likelihood of a bacterial infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is used to diagnose central nervous system infections, such as meningitis, when meningeal signs are present. This child lacks neck stiffness or other meningeal signs, and the rash and oral ulcers suggest a viral exanthem, not a central nervous system infection.

D) CORRECT:

The presentation of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and vesicular rash on the palms and soles, along with painful oral ulcers, is indicative of hand, foot, and mouth disease, commonly caused by coxsackievirus. This viral infection is self-limiting, and management is supportive. The child shows signs of dehydration, such as dry mucous membranes and decreased urine output, making adequate hydration crucial. Supportive care includes fluid replacement, antipyretics for fever, and analgesics for oral discomfort. Antibiotics or antivirals are unnecessary in uncomplicated cases.

Key learning point: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease is characterized by fever, sore throat, and a rash with spots and blisters on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks, with oral ulcers; spots on the soles are a common finding.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old boy who presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, oral vesicular lesions, and a nonpruritic rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet, as shown in the photograph. Which one of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

In children, parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears a few days after the onset of fever. However, the rash of erythema infectiosum is characterized by malar erythema (“slapped cheek” appearance), circumoral pallor, and lace-like or reticular lesions on the trunk. Neither vesicular lesions nor the involvement of palms and soles would be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. Oral vesicles can easily rupture and cause painful ulcers. In some cases, the arms, legs, and buttocks are also affected. The illness is typically self-limiting. Coxsackie A virus can also cause pharyngitis and herpangina.

Unlike coxsackie A virus, coxsackie B virus does not cause oral or cutaneous disease. It instead causes acute myocarditis, pericarditis, and pleurodynia.

Key learning point: Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a self-limited illness caused by Coxsackie A virus, presenting with oral vesicles and a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. However, the rubella exanthem is maculopapular rather than vesicular and it typically begins behind the ears before spreading caudally with sparing of the palms and soles. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis due to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular oral lesions. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is not usually associated with a rash, HSV-1 infection can trigger erythema multiforme (EM). EM, which typically begins on the extremities before spreading to the palms and soles, can also present as a papulovesicular rash. However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: You are seeing an 18-month-old boy who is previously healthy and fully immunized. He presents with a 3-day history of fever and rash. His temperature is 39.0°C, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 34/min. He has a rash on his hands and feet (see figure) and oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum is a common pediatric condition caused by infection with parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a slapped-cheek appearance and a lacy reticular rash on the torso and extremities. It does not cause a vesicular eruption.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by coxsackievirus A16. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is characterized by a vesicular eruption on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet. Cutaneous vesicles are typically surrounded by an erythematous base and will eventually ulcerate. Oral vesicles are usually located on the buccal mucosa and tongue and are mildly painful.

Treatment for hand, foot, and mouth disease is supportive, and most children recover within one week.

The differential diagnosis for hand, foot, and mouth disease includes other vesicle-causing infections such as herpangina, varicella-zoster virus, and herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of fever with vesicular rash on the palms, soles, and interdigital surfaces of the hands and feet, as well as oral vesicles on the posterior palate and tongue, of a fully immunized 18-month-old child is hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by infection with coxsackievirus A16.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpangina, which is also caused by an enterovirus, is an acute febrile illness that leads to small vesicles and ulcers in the posterior oropharynx but not on the extremities as in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

HSV types 1 and 2 can cause herpetic gingivostomatitis and herpetic whitlow (an infection of the digits), but lesions are usually confined to the anterior mouth — and when present on extraoral surfaces such as digits, they are usually singular, not scattered bilaterally over the palms and soles as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella lesions tend to appear more centrally on the body and to spare the palms and soles. Although a single vaccine is not completely protective, wild-type disease is becoming rarer with universal vaccination.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, rash, and pain with oral intake. Physical examination shows ulcers in the posterior oral cavity and a macular rash on his hands and feet. An image of his feet are shown. The mother reports that several children at daycare have had similar symptoms. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is not indicated for hand, foot, and mouth disease, which typically manifests with characteristic oral ulcerations and cutaneous lesions on the hands and feet without respiratory symptoms or pulmonary involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

A rapid strep test is not necessary for this patient. The clinical presentation includes characteristic oral ulcerations in the posterior oral cavity combined with the distinctive macular rash on the hands and feet, which is diagnostic of hand, foot, and mouth disease.

C) INCORRECT:

IV acyclovir is not indicated for hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by coxsackieviruses rather than herpes simplex virus. Antiviral agents are not routinely recommended for coxsackievirus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a viral infection caused by coxsackieviruses and does not respond to antibiotic therapy. Oral amoxicillin is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Supportive care is the most appropriate management for hand, foot, and mouth disease, as this coxsackievirus infection is self-limited with lesions resolving after 7–10 days. Treatment focuses on symptom management with acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever and pain, ensuring adequate hydration, and addressing odynophagia with soft foods and cold liquids.
